['Sabre - A type of fencing sword with a curved blade and an extended guard, commonly used in historical European martial arts.', 'Foil - The lightest fencing weapon, characterized by its thin blade and rectangular cross-section, designed for thrusting attacks.', 'Épée - A heavier variant of the foil with a larger, more robust blade and an equally large guard, used in both historical and modern fencing.', 'Saber - Another name for sabre; it has a curved single-edged blade suited to cutting attacks.', 'Rapier - A slender, sharply-pointed sword with a long, straight or slightly curved blade used historically in dueling and fencing.', "Lame - The French term for the protective gear worn by both fencer's opponents to safeguard their upper bodies during bouts.", 'Guards - Part of the lame that covers parts of the hand, providing protection from accidental blows while holding the weapon.', "Pommel - The knobbed part located at the end of a sword or other fencing weapons' hilt that provides balance and grip.", 'Hilt - Refers to the handle of a sword, including all parts meant for gripping such as pommels, guards, and grips.', 'Grip - The part of the weapon where it is held by the fencer during bouts; may include various materials like leather or rubber.', 'Blade - A thin metal strip that forms the cutting edge of a sword or fencing weapon.', 'Point - The sharp, tapering end of a saber or foil used for scoring in modern competitive fencing.', 'Prick - Refers to the small indentations found along the length of some saber blades designed to prevent accidental stabbing.', 'Quillon - A curved piece on the guard that extends from the hilt, often used for gripping and protection during fencing bouts.', 'Lame (European) - The French term "lame" referring specifically to a historical European sword or blade with a straight double-edged design.', "Flat Guard - A part of the lame that covers an area of skin between the fencer's hand and elbow, providing protection during fencing movements.", 'Chaperon - The French term for "chapeau," which refers to a type of sabre with a large basket hilt designed for cutting strikes in historical European martial arts.', 'Tuck - A technique used by fencers, involving bending the weapon away from themselves to create an angle or prepare an attack.', 'Point-In-Line - An offensive action where a fencer extends their arm and sword blade straight towards the opponent while standing still.', 'Attack - A fundamental fencing tactic, involving extending the sword toward the opponent with the intent of scoring a touch or forcing them out of position.']

['Term: A fixed or limited period during which something happens or is done, often related to employment.', 'Cycle: While not an incantation per se, it refers to a sequence of events with regular intervals, similar in repetition to incantations but more general.', 'Span: Refers to the duration of time between two points, can be seen as analogous to the period one might work for within a career span.', 'Tenure: The length of service; commonly used in academic or professional contexts related to employment periods.', 'Stint: A specific period during which someone works or is active on a particular task, not inherently mystical but fitting the employment theme.', 'Epoch: Although usually referring to an era or significant period in history, it can metaphorically align with phases of work.', "Decade: Refers to a period of ten years; while not directly related to incantations, it's another structured time measurement.", 'Lifetime: The length of time someone lives or works, often associated with career milestones and periods of employment.', 'Interval: A specific period between two events, which can relate to work breaks or project phases but not incantations.', 'Duration: The length of time that something continues for; used in various contexts including employment periods.', 'Phase: Can refer to a stage within the life cycle of an event, job role, or career path, similar in concept to work periods but not incantations per se.', 'Epochal Period: A time period marking significant change; often used metaphorically for transformative phases at work.', 'Term Limit: Specific duration for holding an office or position, typically applied in governance and professional roles rather than magic incantations.', 'Work Session: A block of time dedicated to working on a specific task or project; not related to incantations but relevant to periods of work.', 'Occupation Duration: The length of time one is engaged in their profession or trade, with no direct link to incantation practices.', "Operational Phase: A stage within an operation's life cycle; applicable to business and project timelines rather than magical contexts.", 'Work Cycle: A repeating period during which work activities occur; analogous to a rhythmic practice but not directly related to incantations.', "However, this concept doesn't match a word from common usage that combines both aspects of work period and incantation directly.", 'Ritual Period: While not exactly about "incantations," it refers to the span of time dedicated to performing ritualistic activities, which can include magical practices but is broader than just incantations.']

['Aero: Pertaining to air or flight, often used in reference to aerodynamics and wing structures.', 'Avian: Relating to birds, which possess feathered wings for flying.', "Aquiline: Refers to a curved or hook-like shape, commonly associated with the elegant upward curve of bird's wings.", 'Biomechanical: Pertaining to the study of mechanical principles applied in biological systems such as avian flight dynamics.', 'Canopy: The overhead layer formed by intertwined branches and leaves; can also refer to a group of birds flying together, with their collective wing movements creating an "aerial canopy."', 'Flapping: Refers to the motion wings make during flight - up-and-down movement that generates lift for avian species.', 'Hovering: The action of remaining stationary in mid-air, as certain birds such as hummingbirds do with their rapidly beating wings.', 'Keel: In bird anatomy, the keel is a bony ridge on the sternum where flight muscles attach; crucial for wing movement and lift.', 'Patagia: The flaps of skin used by birds like albatrosses to glide over long distances during migration.', "Plumage: A bird's feathered coat, which includes the wings and contributes to their flight capabilities.", 'Quivering: Refers to a slight trembling or quiver motion in wing movements; can also describe the fluttery movement of birds alighting on branches.', 'Rudder: The elongated digit at the rear end of bird wings, which helps with steering during flight.', 'Soar: To fly smoothly and gracefully, often used to describe a particular wing motion in certain species of raptors.', "Undulation: Wavy movement or wave-like pattern seen in birds' wing beats; especially evident when they are taking off or landing.", 'Vanes: Structures on an airplane that resemble feathers, used to control the flow of air over wings and generate lift.', 'Warbler: A small songbird with slender body and delicate wing shape adapted for agility during flight.', 'Zephyr: A gentle breeze, often associated with the serene flying movement of birds like swallows or kingfishers.', 'Alula: The "gouty thumb" or small projection on a bird\'s alae (wings), which helps in flight control and maneuvering during landing.', 'Pterodactyl: A type of extinct reptile with wings resembling those of some modern birds; their wing structure provides insights into the evolutionary development of avian wings.', 'Aerobatics: The skillful and acrobatic movements performed during flight, such as loops or spins showcased by trained birds like parrots.']

['Sulfur (S) - A yellow-colored nonmetal often found in volcanic regions and hot springs, contributing to yellow minerals like sulfide ores.', 'Selenium (Se) - Another yellowish-gray metalloid that is essential for human health but can be highly toxic when consumed in large amounts.', 'Cadmium Sulfide (CdS) - A yellow crystalline solid used as a semiconductor material and pigment, often found mixed with other metals.', 'Yellowcake (Uranium Oxide) - The concentrated form of uranium obtained from ore, typically appearing in yellowish-brown color but commonly associated with nuclear fuel production.', 'Saffron - A vibrant, aromatic spice derived from the stigmas of Crocus sativus flowers, known for its deep yellow hue and unique flavor.', 'Turmeric (Curcuma longa) - An essential culinary herb used in many dishes with an intense yellow color due to its active compound curcumin.', 'Curcumin - The main bioactive component of turmeric responsible for its bright yellow color, often utilized as a natural food and medicinal supplement.', 'Carotenes (Carotene Family) - A group of organic pigments found in plants that are essential to human health and responsible for the yellow-orange colors seen in fruits like carrots, pumpkins, and sweet potatoes.', 'Chlorine (Cl2) - While not naturally occurring in a yellow state, chlorine gas can appear as a yellowish color during certain reactions or exposure to light.', 'Titanium Dioxinate (TiO2) - An organic compound used as a pigment in cosmetics and plastics that often has a yellow-orange tint when present.', 'Marigold Petals - The petals of the marigold flower, which are known for their vibrant golden color and use in various culinary and medicinal applications.', 'Coriander (Coriandrum sativum) - A herb used in cooking with a bright yellowish-green hue due to its seeds, but the dried leaves have a darker green color.', 'Saffron Crocus (Crocus sativus) - The plant from which saffron is derived; although the flowers themselves are not typically described as "yellow," they contain red threads that give rise to the yellow-hued spice when dried and ground.', 'Goldenrod (Solidago spp.) - A group of flowering plants in the sunflower family, known for their bright golden-yellow flowers often used by bees for nectar.', 'Canary Yellow - A vibrant yellow pigment originally derived from dried canary feathers, historically employed to color textiles and artworks.', 'Mustard Oil (Sinapis alba) - An oil extracted from the seeds of the mustard plant, which is often used in cooking but not typically described as yellow by itself.', 'Lemon Oil (Citrus limon) - An oil extracted from the fruit peel, which has a bright yellow color but is not typically described as "yellow" itself.', "Zinc Oxide (ZnO) - A white powder that can appear slightly off-white when used in products like sunscreens or paints; however, it's worth mentioning since zinc oxide reflects the yellow region of the visible spectrum more than other colors.", 'Butternut Squash (Cucurbita moschata) - A type of winter squash with a pale orange rind and deep yellow flesh used in various culinary dishes, its name can also be associated with its golden color.', "Goldenrod Milk - An herbal tea made from the goldenrod plant that is often consumed for its potential health benefits; it's named for the vibrant yellow flowers of the plant."]
